contentList.content: Can be washed and used for alchemical experiments
A collection of fine glass flasks, used to distil liquids both mundane and sinister.
The book is worn out and has clearly been in the hands of many students.
This delicate instrument is a common sight in any alchemical shop, but the finest come from Berdusk, carefully packed in straw and sheep's wool and hand-delivered.
Used for setting alchemical ingredients during experiments
A thick glass bottle, meticulously shaped to resist fire and distribute heat evenly.
This alchemical tool has seen years of use, its metal frame well-rusted and its glass stained a dozen shades of sapphire.
Neutralises the effects of all poisons.

Cures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blinded</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SILENCED">Silenced</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PARALYZED">Paralysed</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="POISONED">Poisoned</LSTag> creatures.

Affected entity falls asleep for 2 rounds. When it wakes up, it receives the effects of a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>. If interrupted before the duration expires, the effects do not apply.

Affected entity falls asleep for 2 rounds. When it wakes up, it receives the effects of a Short Rest and all 1st and 2nd level spell slots are restored.

If interrupted before the duration expires, the effects will not apply.

Has Advantage on Attack Rolls and imposes Disadvantage on enemy Attack Rolls.

Invisibility ends early if the invisible entity attacks, casts another spell, interacts with an object, takes an action or bonus action, or is damaged.
Gain resistance to Necrotic damage until your next Long Rest.
Gain resistance to Psychic damage until your next Long Rest.
Drink to gain a +5 bonus to Initiative. In addition, you can't be <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SURPRISED">Surprised</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
An acrid, coppery aroma wafts from this liquid, clearing the senses and honing awareness.

Drink to fall into a 2-turn slumber. Unless interrupted, you gain the benefits of a <LSTag Tooltip="ShortRest">Short Rest</LSTag> and regain all 1st and 2nd Level <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slots</LSTag>. If you are awoken before the duration expires, the effects will not apply.
The motion of the shimmering liquid going back and forth in its vial is somnambulant - you know drinking it will bring the comfort of a warm, enveloping blanket.

Drink to gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="Concentration">Concentration</LSTag> saves, and against being <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="CHARMED">Charmed</LSTag>. Magic can't put you to sleep. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
A spellcaster who cannot maintain their spells is about as useful as a chocolate kettle.
Gain 10 <LSTag Tooltip="TemporaryHitPoints">temporary hit points</LSTag> and become <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLESS">Blessed</LSTag>.
Flasks filled with this potion are often passed around by soldiers at first light on the dawn of battle.

Gain <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ALCH_ELIXIR_TADPOLE">Psionic Weakening</LSTag> and <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ALCH_ELIXIR_TADPOLE_ADVANTAGE">Psionic Enrichment</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Stimulates the pineal gland in the brain, unlocking malevolent power.

Drink to increase your size. Weapons deal an additional 1d4 damage. You gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on Strength <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Checks</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Instantly upon inhaling this elixir, your abdomen seems to swell, and the muscles in your back feel like sheets of hammer-beaten steel.
Drink to increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> to 16. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Before your eyes, the elixir firms into a tough, striated twig, then it liquefies once more.
Gain an additional Level [1] <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
A small bottle, filled to the brim with arcane energy.
Gain an additional Level [1] <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
From hedge wizards to high priests, these elixirs are coveted by spellcasters of any ilk.
Gain an additional Level [1] <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Even through the thick glass, the arcane energy contained within this bottle makes your fingers tingle.
Gain an additional Level [1] <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
It is said that the glimmer in this elixir is the reflection of light on the Weave itself.
Drink to fall into a 2-turn slumber. Unless interrupted, you gain the benefits of a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
One of the few ways for elves to experience sleep. Other methods include taking narcotics and being hit very hard with a chair.
Drink to gain the ability to see in the dark up to [1]. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Enfolded in darkness, monsters and tucked-away treasures hide, glimpsed only by the naturally gifted, and, of course, whosoever imbibes this brackish elixir.

Drink to enter a bloodlust. Once per turn when you kill a foe, you gain [1] <LSTag Tooltip="TemporaryHitPoints">temporary hit points</LSTag> and an additional <LSTag Tooltip="Action">action</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Those willing to immerse themselves in savagery often reap a blood-red reward.
Thick as molten iron with a taste to match. Coats you from your throat to your fingertips.
The number you need to roll to land a <LSTag Tooltip="CriticalHit">Critical Hit</LSTag> is reduced by 1. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
The syrupy liquid languidly swirling inside this bottle somehow reminds you of a predator lying in wait.
Drink to increase the effectiveness of your spells. You will gain [1] <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="MAG_GISH_ARCANE_ACUITY">Arcane Acuity</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Derived from the eye of a mage-hunting Nothic, this elixir waxes from within with a piercing light.

Your <LSTag Tooltip="MovementSpeed">movement speed</LSTag> can't be reduced by <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DIFFICULT_TERRAIN">Difficult Terrain</LSTag> or spells. You can't be <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PARALYZED">Paralysed</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="RESTRAINED">Restrained</LSTag>. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Though textured like half-frozen honey, this liquid flows as effortlessly as mercury.
Drink this elixir to spot Invisible creatures. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Beneath its vial of glass the liquid floods with colour, goes translucent, and becomes colourful once more - a pretty fluctuation.
Drink to probe into the minds of those around you. You will be able to read the thoughts of certain creatures while speaking with them.
Fragments of memory and perception smatter this liquid - a crude constellation of thought.
Alchemy is available to any character with an Intelligence of at least 14 or to druids with a Wisdom of at least 14.
To mix potions with additional statuses, the alchemist's base attribute (intelligence or wisdom for a druid) must be at least 14.
A set of glass retorts, flasks and funnels, ready for any alchemical experiments
A collection of fine glass flasks, used to distil liquids both mundane and sinister.
Each cylinder, flask and retort in this set is covered in a sticky, dusty substance.
A set of flasks, the main purpose of which is separation
Each cylinder, flask and retort in this set is covered in a sticky, dusty substance.

For alchemical experiments, you need to put a clean flask with the necessary ingredients in each slot according to the recipe:
Slot 1 - base and catalyst (if necessary)
Slot 2 - secondary ingredients
Slot 3 - additional ingredients

* you can conduct several experiments at the same time, but the more ingredients, the more difficult it is to control the experiment.
Though rust has bitten into this iron stand, the glass flasks it holds are in pristine condition.
Though rust has bitten into this iron stand, the glass flasks it holds are in pristine condition.
Though rust has bitten into this iron stand, the glass flasks it holds are in pristine condition.
A built-up of soot, dust, and a mysterious blue liquid has settled in every nook and cranny of this alchemical set.
A built-up of soot, dust, and a mysterious blue liquid has settled in every nook and cranny of this alchemical set.
A built-up of soot, dust, and a mysterious blue liquid has settled in every nook and cranny of this alchemical set.
A greasy substance clogs up most of this set's spiralling condenser, making any distillation a risky business.
A greasy substance clogs up most of this set's spiralling condenser, making any distillation a risky business.
A greasy substance clogs up most of this set's spiralling condenser, making any distillation a risky business.
Some of the flasks are empty, apart from the output flask.
A small but heavy bar of adamantine, an extremely rare and precious material first crafted by dwarves. It can be used to forge powerful weapons and armour.
A small but heavy bar of exquisite mithral, manufactured at the High House of Gond.
The glow of this liquid resembles the night sky, and its use in alchemical processes can lead to unexpected results.
Heat-resistant glass was first invented by a gnome wizard trying to make imitation quartz. Although she deemed the experiment a failure - and lost an eye - her accidental creation made her rich.
Soot coats the bottom of the glass - even its iron stand is marred by scorch-marks.
This delicate instrument is a common sight in any alchemical shop, but the finest come from Berdusk, carefully packed in straw and sheep's wool and hand-delivered.
A thick glass bottle, meticulously shaped to resist fire and distribute heat evenly.
This alchemical tool has seen years of use, its metal frame well-rusted and its glass stained a dozen shades of sapphire.
Soot covers the bottom of the glass, as well as its iron stand.
Can be washed and used for setting alchemical ingredients during experiments.
Necessary as a catalyst for some alchemical experiments.
The mandatory conditions of the recipe are not met, read the recipe again more carefully.
Due to the lack of a catalyst in the first flask, it was not possible to add an additional status to the created item.
The Sword Coast's finest well water, bottled for convenience.
Slightly cloudy, but safe to drink.
Once a recipe is learned, the knowledge becomes available to anyone on your team who has the necessary skills.

To separate potions, elixirs, poisons or grenades into their ingredients, you need to place a clean flask in each slot, with the first slot containing the catalyst and what is being separated, and the second slot for the separated ingredients.

To distill liquids, you need to put a clean flask in each slot, with the ingredients in the first slot and the second slot for distilled liquids.
The standard recipe is an alchemical catalyst, which requires water and alcohol (wine - two bottles, strong alcohol - one).
A new recipe has been learned
You've learned the recipe! The knowledge becomes available to anyone on your team who has the necessary skills.
Not enough knowledge to create an item using the recipe.
The experiment did not give any results. Check the recipes and ingredients.

Notes on the Transmutation of Metals

Long years of research have finally led me to one single stable sequence of alchemical transformations that allows you to obtain... yes, you can obtain any metal you desire!
To obtain gold, for example, you will need a bar of the original metal and any gold object that is not spoiled by spells.
The following is a detailed description that will be understandable only to true alchemists...

* a catalyst is required for successful unification.

Recipe for combining healing potions

Combining similar healing potions is essentially a fairly simple process, but you must strictly adhere to the sequence of actions so as not to damage the original material.
The main principle is that each potion is a combination of two potions of the previous level, that is, to get a Potion of Excellent Healing, you can combine two Potions of Great Healing, or one Potion of Great Healing and two simple Potions of Healing

Put one potion into the main flask of the laboratory, and the rest in the secondary (one the same as the main one, or two lower levels).
You can use the third flask to obtain additional properties by putting in the necessary ingredient, if you have enough knowledge.

* a catalyst is required for successful combining.

ALCHEMICAL ENCYCLOPEDIA

This encyclopedia contains commonly known recipes for alchemical potions, elixirs, and poisons. These recipes are available to anyone with sufficient intelligence and basic alchemical skills.

POTIONS

Antidote - Neutralizes the effects of all poisons.
Recipe: Salts of Mugwort + Any Suspension

Potion of Angelic Reprieve - Drink to fall into a 2-turn slumber. Unless interrupted, you gain the benefits of a Short Rest and regain all 1st and 2nd Level spell slots.
Recipe: Essence of Unicorn Horn + Any Salt

Potion of Angelic Slumber - Drink to fall into a 2-turn slumber. Unless interrupted, you gain the benefits of a Long Rest.
Recipe: Essence of Planetar Feather + Any Suspension

Potion of Animal Speaking - Gain the ability to comprehend and verbally communicate with beasts until your next Long Rest.
Recipe: Essence of Acorn Truffle + Any Salt

Potion of Feather Fall - Drink to slow your rate of descent during falls and gain Immunity to falling damage.
Recipe: Sublimate of Autumncrocus + Any Essence

Potion of Flying - Drink to gain the ability to Fly.
Recipe: Sublimate of Eagle Feather + Any Essence

Potion of Glorious Vaulting - Drink this to triple your Jump distance.
Recipe: Sublimate of Wispweed + Any Ashes

Potion of Greater Healing - 4d4 Healing.
Recipe: Ashes of Balsam + Any Salt

Potion of Healing - 2d4 Healing.
Recipe: Salts of Rogue's Morsel + Any Suspension

Potion of Invisibility - Turn Invisible. The condition ends early if you attack or cast a spell.
Recipe: Ashes of Imp Patagium + Any Essence

Potion of Mind Reading - Drink to probe into the minds of those around you.
Recipe: Suspension of Mergrass + Any Suspension

Potion of Speed - Become Hastened. Gain an extra action, +2 to Armor Class, Advantage on Dexterity Saving Throws, and double Movement Speed. When the condition ends, become Lethargic.
Recipe: Ashes of Hyena Ear + Any Salt

Potion of Superior Healing - 8d4 Healing.
Recipe: Salts of Musk Creeper + Any Suspension

Potion of Supreme Healing - 10d4 Healing.
Recipe: Sublimate of Ki-Rin Hair + Any Ashes

Remedial Potion - Cures Blinded, Silenced, Paralyzed, and Poisoned creatures.
Recipe: Salt of Xorn Scales + Any Suspension

ELIXIRS

Elixir of Arcane Cultivation - Gain an additional Level 1 spell slot Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Vitriol of Weavemoss + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Barkskin - Drink to increase Armor Class to 16. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Salts of Tree Bark + Any Suspension

Elixir of Battlemage's Power - Drink to increase the effectiveness of your spells. You will gain 3 Arcane Acuity.
Recipe: Suspension of Gauth Eye + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Bloodlust - Drink to enter a bloodlust. Once per turn when you kill a foe, you gain 5 temporary hit points and an additional action.
Recipe: Ashes of Worg Fang + Any Salt

Elixir of Cloud Giant Strength - Increase your Strength to 27.
Recipe: Salts of Cloud Giant Fingernails + Any Suspension

Elixir of Darkvision - Drink to gain the ability to see in the dark up to 12m.
Recipe: Essence of Crystalline Lens + Any Salt

Elixir of Fire Resistance - You gain Resistance to Fire damage, and can no longer Burn.
Recipe: Ashes of Dragon Egg Mushroom + Any Salt

Elixir of Guileful Movement - Your movement speed can't be reduced by Difficult Terrain or Spells. You can't be Paralyzed or Restrained.
Recipe: Suspension of Ochre Jelly + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Heroism - Gain 10 temporary hit points and become Blessed.
Recipe: Sublimate of Pegasus Feathers + Any Ashes

Elixir of Hill Giant Strength - Increase your Strength to 21.
Recipe: Salts of Hill Giant Fingernails + Any Suspension

Elixir of Lightning Resistance - You gain Resistance to Lightning damage and can no longer be Shocked, Electrocuted, Jolted, or otherwise affected by lightning.
Recipe: Salts of Copper Shavings + Any Suspension

Elixir of Necrotic Resistance - Gain Resistance to Necrotic damage.
Recipe: Vitriol of Oleander + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Peerless Focus - Drink to gain Advantage on Concentration saves, and against being Charmed. Magic can't put you to sleep.
Recipe: Sublimate of Belladonna + Any Ashes

Elixir of Poison Resistance - You gain Resistance to Poison damage and can no longer be Poisoned.
Recipe: Suspension of Muddy Goo + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Psychic Resistance - Gain Resistance to Psychic damage.
Recipe: Suspension of Cerebrospinal Fluid + Any Sublimate

Elixir of See Invisibility - Drink this elixir to spot Invisible creatures.
Recipe: Suspension of Nothic Eye + Any Vitriol

Elixir of The Colossus - Drink to increase your size. Weapons deal an additional 1d4 damage. You gain Advantage on Strength checks and saves.
Recipe: Salts of Chasm Creeper + Any Suspension

Elixir of Universal Resistance - Gain resistance to all damage.
Recipe: Vitriol of Divine Miasma + Any Sublimate

Elixir of Viciousness - The number you need to roll to land Critical Hit is reduced by 1. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Vitriol of Shadowroot Sac + Any Ashes

Elixir of Vigilance - Drink to gain a +5 bonus to Initiative. In addition, you can't be surprised. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Sublimate of Bloodstained Hook + Any Ashes

Greater Elixir of Arcane Cultivation - Gain an additional Level 2 spell slot. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Suspension of Laculite + Any Vitriol

Superior Elixir of Arcane Cultivation - Gain an additional Level 3 spell slot. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Suspension of Night Orchid + Any Vitriol

Supreme Elixir of Arcane Cultivation - Gain an additional Level 4 spell slot. Replaces effects from other elixirs when drunk.
Recipe: Essence of Beholder Eye + Any Suspension

Tadpole Elixir - Psionic Weakening and Psionic Enrichment.
Recipe: Sublimate of Tongue of Madness + Any Essence

COATINGS

Arsonist's Oil - Coat your weapon in an oil that transforms the target's Fire Resistance to Fire Vulnerability. Targets that are immune to Fire Damage are unaffected.
Recipe: Sublimate of Frosted Ears + Any Ashes

Basic Poison - Coat your active weapon with a poison that inflicts an additional 1d4 Poison damage.
Recipe: Vitriol of Bonecap + Any Ashes
Crawler Mucus - Coat your active weapon with poison. Targets must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or become Paralyzed and Poisoned.
Recipe: Salts of Carrion Crawler Tentacle + Any Vitriol

Diluted Oil of Sharpness - Coat your weapon in oil. It gains a +1 bonus to Damage and Attack Rolls, and overcomes resistance to non-magical damage.
Recipe: Salts of Viridian Crystal + Any Vitriol

Drow Poison - Coat your active weapon with poison. Targets must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or become Poisoned and fall Asleep.
Recipe: Essence of Swarming Toadstool + Any Salt

Malice - Coat your active weapon with poison. Targets must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or become Blinded and Poisoned.
Recipe: Vitriol of Lolth's Candle + Any Ashes

Oil of Accuracy - Coat your weapon to receive a +2 bonus to Attack Rolls with the oiled weapon.
Recipe: Ashes of Daggerroot + Any Salt


Oil of Bane - Coat your weapon in oil. Targets failing a Charisma Saving Throw become Baned for 2 turns.
Recipe: Vitriol of Putrefied Tumour + Any Sublimate

Oil of Combustion - On hit, a coated weapon covers its target in oil for 2 turns. Oil-covered targets immolate upon taking fire damage, dealing 3d18 fire damage to everyone and everything nearby.
Recipe: Ashes of Mephit Magma + Any Essence

Oil of Diminution - Coat your weapon in oil: it receives a -1 penalty to damage, but targets failing a Constitution save, suffer Disadvantage on Strength Checks and Saves. They also receive a -1d4 penalty to melee damage.
Recipe: Essence of Sylvan Stone + Any Suspension

Oil of Freezing - Coat your weapon in oil. When you hit a foe, it inflicts Encrusted with Frost for 2 turns.
Recipe: Suspension of Frost Salamander Tongue + Any Ashes

Purple Worm Toxin - Coat your active weapon with toxin that deals an additional 1d10 poison damage. On a successful Constitution Saving Throw, target still takes half damage.
Recipe: Suspension of Purple Worm Slime + Any Vitriol

Serpent Fang Toxin - Coat your active weapon with toxin that deals an additional 1d6 poison damage. On a successful Constitution saving throw, target still takes half damage.
Recipe: Suspension of Snake Venom + Any Vitriol

Simple Toxin - Coat your active weapon with toxin that deals an additional 1d4 poison damage. On a successful Constitution saving throw, target still takes half damage.
Recipe: Suspension of Bullywug Trumpet + Any Sublimate

Thisobald's Brewed-Up Bellyglummer - Coat your active weapon in poison. Targets must succeed a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned and take 1d6 Poison damage at the end of each of its turns.
Recipe: Salts of Corpse Rose + Any Suspension

Wizardsbane Oil - Coat your weapon and targets receive -3 penalty to Spell Attack Rolls and Spell Save DC, Disadvantage on Saving Throws for maintaining Concentration for 2 turns.
Recipe: Essence of Gremishka Tail + Any Suspension

Wyvern Toxin - Coat your active weapon with toxin that deals an additional 1d8 Poison damage. On a successful Constitution Saving Throw, target still takes half damage.
Recipe: Ashes of Wyvern Stinger + Any Salt
GRENADES

Alchemist's Fire - Hurl a flask of liquid fire that explodes on impact.
Recipe: Ashes of Fire Amber + Any Salt

Flashblinder - Blind a target. If it is a steel watcher or scrying eye, it is stunned, and suffers a -1d6 penalty to Attack Rolls.
Recipe: Sublimate of Behir Scales + Any Ashes

Fungal Bamboozler - Lob this vaporous decoction to Befuddle nearby foes.
Recipe: Timmask Spores + Any Salt

Haste Spore Grenade - Explodes in a cloud of invigorating energy that Hastens creatures within.
Recipe: Sublimate of Haste Spores + Any Essence

Hearthlight Bomb - Bathe a nearby target in light. Illuminates a 9m radius.
Recipe: Essence of Nightlight + Any Suspension

Noxious Spore Grenade - Explodes in a virulent cloud that can inflict Noxious Fumes upon creatures within.
Recipe: Sublimate of Poison Spores + Any Ashes
Web Grenade - Explodes into a tanglty mess that Enwebs creatures caught within.
Recipe: Suspension of Spider Silk + Any Vitriol

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
* recipes were collected and systematized by the famous collector of knowledge known as the Web Weaver, with the modest assistance of an alchemist from the northern lands.
Neutralizes the effects of poisons up to uncommon rarity.

A powerful antidote courses through your veins, neutralizing the effects of all poisons. You also have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> against being Poisoned and Resistance to Poison damage.
Neutralizes the effects of all poisons. Gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> against being Poisoned and Resistance to Poison damage.
Blessed by the Oak Father himself, this tonic will cure even the most baneful poisons.
Neutralizes the effects of poisons up to uncommon rarity.
This concoction appears rather chewable, thick as it is with herbs and roots.

Thoughts on countering strong poisons

The scroll contains the results of the druids' study of most known poisons and their ingredients. And it seems that after numerous experiments they were able to come up with a recipe for a very powerful antidote, called the Elixir of Silvanus!

Its power is such that it not only instantly removes the effect of all known poisons and toxins, but also greatly increases resistance to poisons!

Recipe: Salts of Mugwort + (2 Essence of Swarming Toadstool + Ashes of Wyvern Stingers + Salts of Tree Bark), also don't forget about the catalyst and... Blessing of Silvanus, whatever that means...
Unable to separate source material. Check that the first flask contains catalyst and suitable potions or grenades.
Cannot distill inserted items. Check what you inserted into the first flask.
There are not enough alchemical ingredients in the flasks for experiments
A well-worn book, someone memorized it very diligently

ALCHEMIST'S NOTEBOOK
* for keeping notes on the alchemical art and recipes found during travels.

Gold Bar - Opens every door.
Recipe: Non-gold metalbar + Unenchanted Golden Item (ring, cup, etc.). atalyst is required.

Combined Healing Potions - Allows you to receive improved healing.
Recipes: Potion + Potion, Potion + 2 Potions(-1 lvl), Potion + 4 Potions(-2 lvl), Potion + Potion(-1 lvl) + 2 Potions(-2 lvl). atalyst is required.

Elixir of Silvanus - Neutralizes the effects of all poisons. Also provides Advantage on Saving Throws against being Poisoned and Resistance to Poison damage.
Recipe: Salts of Mugwort + 2 Essence of Swarming Toadstool + Ashes of Wyvern Stingers + Salts of Tree Bark. Catalist and Druid Origin is required.

BASIC ALCHEMY
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Alchemy can be practiced by any character with an intelligence of 14 or higher, or by druids with a wisdom of 14 or higher.
For various alchemical experiments, several alchemical sets are available, found in the world, which have different purposes:
1. Combiners - creating potions and grenades.
2. Distillers - obtaining distillates and catalysts.
3. Separators - separating potions into their components.
You can also find flasks, retorts and funnels, which will be needed for experiments as containers for ingredients.

* instructions for use are on the tools.
* alchemists with a primary attribute of 17 or higher can add additional ingredients and mix potions with two statuses.
* recipes always list the main ingredient first, followed by secondary ingredients and additional requirements, if any.
A small leather pouch with a drawstring, usually used for storing tobacco.
Tobacco mix of mugwort and belladonna, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_MUGWORT_BELLADONNA_STATUS">a short-term concentration</LSTag>.
A plain leather bag, cinched at the top with knotted cord.
A small leather pouch with a drawstring, usually used for storing tobacco.
The pipe is filled with Regular Tobacco, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_MUGWORT_BELLADONNA_STATUS">a short-term concentration</LSTag>.

Affected entity's ability to maintain its spells has increased.

It has Advantage to Saving Throws against being Charmed and for maintaining Concentration.
Tieflings from Zariel's bloodline are empowered with martial strength, and can channel searing flame to punish their enemies.
Even a generation apart, forest blood breeds true. These half-elves retain their parent's gift for speed, but tend to wander rather than staying in hidden enclaves.
You're a champion of the common people, challenging tyrants and monsters to protect the helpless. Saving people in imminent danger will make your legend grow.
Ilmater is the god of suffering and endurance. His clerics defend the oppressed and take on the burdens of others, leading to a reputation as martyrs among common folk.
Being raised in the Underdark casts a cruel shadow on one's view of the world, even up on the surface.
Tempus is the god of war. His clerics welcome conflict through force of arms, but only abide honourable combat and courageous action.
Durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faern.
Raised in one of the distant and hostile regions of Faern, an outlander can survive in the outdoors with very little.
Reclusive and wise, wood elves are primarily found in the forests of Faern. Rigorous training makes them masters of archery and camouflage, enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.
Someone who's survived breaking the law time and again. Intimidation and connections are their best protection.
With an ethereal countenance and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature and its power. Flourishing in light and darkness alike, an elf can be beautiful and terrifying in equal measure.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
Tempus is the god of war, and his paladins are honourable but fearsome foes. They keep the world in balance with force of arms and unwavering courage.
The most common face to see in Faern, humans often face stiff competition from long-lived races, but hold their own with tenacity, creativity, and an endless capacity for growth.
Myrkul is the god of death and decay. Paladins who worship him are rare, but those who do are harbingers of a horrific demise for all those around them.
You are a female of one of the races; you are perceived as female by those that encounter you.
You are a male of one of the races; you are perceived as male by those that encounter you.
While more guarded than surface gnomes, deep gnomes are known for their loyalty and cunning. Their darkvision and training in stealth keep them alive in the hostile Underdark.
Mystra is the goddess of all magic. Her paladins guard magical lore and artefacts with their lives, ensuring their goddess' power is preserved from one generation to the next.

Raised in one of Lolth's massive cults spread throughout the Underdark, these drow extol the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess, seeking to bring all other drow under her sway. Lolth marks her followers with vivid red eyes, in hope every race in Faern will learn to fear the very sight of them.
Clerics channel the power of the gods they worship, wielding potent magic and acting as representatives of divine authority.
Masters of tactics and combat, fighters are the product of rigorous and relentless training. They move in armour like a second skin, and can wield any weapon with unmatched skill.

You have spent your life in service to a temple, learning sacred rites and providing sacrifices to the god or gods you worship. Manifestations of gods, along with their sacred works, guide you to greatness.
Bound by a deal to a powerful patron, warlocks trade their loyalty for supernatural abilities and unique magic.
Good clerics seek to better the world, empowered by their deities to heal others and destroy the undead. Selne, Ilmater, Tyr, and Mystra are common gods they worship.
Reclusive and wise, wood elves are primarily found in the forests of Faern. Rigorous training makes them masters of archery and camouflage, enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.
Evil clerics are driven to conquer and corrupt Faern in service to their gods. Shar, Bhaal, Bane, and Myrkul are common gods they worship.
To be half-drow is to wrestle with a violent and complicated legacy. Cleverness and tenacity serve them well, for they are caught between two very different worlds.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Mind flayers are aberrations that feed off brains and dominate others with pure psionic will. They create more of their own kind using tadpoles that consume a host from the inside out.
Even a generation apart, forest blood breeds true. These half-elves retain their parent's gift for speed, but tend to wander rather than staying in hidden enclaves.

Some undead seek to return to life; others long for the sweet embrace of oblivion. They move amongst the other races unseen, apex predators who can't afford detection. Lately, an unfamiliar voice beckons to them from a world unknown.
Heirs of the mystical Feywild, high elves value magic in all its forms, and even those who do not study spellcraft can manipulate the Weave.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Raised in an honourable - if brutally aggressive - martial culture, hobgoblins revel in the beauty of warfare. They also try to keep an iron boot on their chaotic goblinoid cousins.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Helm, the Vigilant One, is the god of those who guard and defend others. His paladins are steadfast protectors, holding the line against impossible odds no matter the cost.
Fuelled by the Oath they swore to uphold justice and righteousness, most paladins are a beacon of hope in dark times.
An enthusiastic adventurer of remarkable spirit and mettle.
This corpse has been the target of a Speak with Dead spell.
Oghma is the god of knowledge. His paladins go on dangerous quests to restore lost lore, and put their lives on the line to protect strongholds of knowledge like Oghma's libraries.
Your previous oath was one of Ancients.
Heirs of the mystical Feywild, high elves value magic in all its forms, and even those who do not study spellcraft can manipulate the Weave.
Wealth and power define the nobility, but some families fare more successfully than others. A good name goes far, though.
A life spent in seclusion grants a clear mind, but makes the chaos of society distasteful.
Identifies traps as organic, so they can go "squish" and otherwise not behave like mechanical ones.
Yondalla is the mother-goddess of the halflings. Her clerics view her as a strong and protective parent who bestows them with luck, and whose example should be followed.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells - by blood or curse - tieflings face constant suspicion in Faern. Their arcane abilities make them natural survivors, whether as heroes or villains.
Your previous oath was of the Devotion.

Survivors of Lolth's treachery against Corellon Larethian, Seldarine drow live in a scattered collection of Underdark city-states, warring with each other as often as the Spider Queen's cult. Many of these drow travel to the surface in search of aid, seeking to reunite their shattered people at any cost.
A step further from the Feywild than their high elf parent, these half-elves still hold a magical spark. They mature faster than their brethren, but only live a few decades longer than humans.
Ilmater is the god of suffering and endurance. His paladins are martyrs in the truest sense, taking on the burdens of the oppressed until their last breath.
Cleaving arcane magic to musical artistry, bards are performers without compare. They draw on songs empowered by spells, inspiring their allies and toppling their enemies.
Bane is the god of hatred, fear, and tyranny. His clerics are spartan, ruthless conquerors, gathering as much power as they can under Bane's banner.
Unable to speak, by nature or by magic.
Descended from the archdevil Mephistopheles, these tieflings are gifted with a particular affinity for arcane magic.
Lolth is the evil drow goddess of deceit, shadows, and spiders. Her clerics execute the will of the Spider Queen, weaving a complicated web of schemes and treachery.
Moradin, father of the dwarves, is the god of creation, smithing, stonework and protection. His paladins are champions and guardians, leading the charge against age-old dwarven enemies.
With this spell, one can read the thoughts of certain creatures.
A member of the lawful evil fiends that hail from Baator.
A servant of mind flayers that feeds on the intelligence of sentient beings.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
The strong embrace the wild that hides inside - keen instincts, primal physicality, and most of all, an unbridled, unquenchable rage.
Good paladins are bastions of heroism, willing to make any sacrifice to honour their Oath and their quest. Their abilities are gifted by gods like Tyr, Selne, Ilmater, and Mystra.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their centuries-long lifespans to explore and invent in Faern's brightest corners and darkest depths.
The Watchful Protector is the king of gnomish gods - a deity of humour, gem-cutting, protection, and trickery.

The elves of the Underdark, drow have been fighting a massive civil war since the goddess Lolth severed herself from the elvish pantheon, a betrayal scarring every generation that followed. Drow city-states struggle with one another for dominance, but the true war is between the cultists who serve Lolth and those who resist the goddess' corruption.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Druids channel the elemental forces of nature and share a deep kinship with animals. Mastery of Wild Shape allows them to transform into beasts from all over the Realms.
Following the ideal of the knight in shining armour, you act with honour and virtue in the pursuit of the greater good.
Laduguer is the patron of the duergar and god of self-reliance, defence, and survival. His clerics honour him by acquiring more power and wealth through any means possible.
An enthusiastic adventurer of remarkable spirit and mettle.
The duergar - grey dwarves - were once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayer race, and adapted to freedom with grim cruelty. Their stealth and viciousness makes them feared throughout the Underdark.
A source of illumination and divination.
Eilistraee is the drow goddess of song, beauty, swordwork, hunting, and moonlight. As the patron of drow who reject the evils of their society, she instructs her clerics to offer light and hope.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their centuries-long lifespans to explore and invent in Faern's brightest corners and darkest depths.
While more guarded than surface gnomes, deep gnomes are known for their loyalty and cunning. Their darkvision and training in stealth keep them alive in the hostile Underdark.
Neutral paladins stand as archetypes of balance and justice, defending the world against extremes. Their quests are consecrated by deities like Helm, Kelemvor, Oghma, and Tempus.

Vlaakith, the dread lich queen of the githyanki, demands and receives utter obedience from her subjects. For clerics, their faith in their revered queen is so strong that it manifests as clerical magic.
Wizards master the arcane by specialising in individual schools of magic, combining ancient spells with modern research.
Mountain dwarves thrive in rugged terrain, standing taller than their hill dwarf cousins. Their kingdoms are a bastion of strength in northern Faern.
Half-elves inherit blessings from both their parents, but at the price of never quite fitting in. Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere - yet struggle to stay for long.
Kylin, A servant of Tymora, Goddess of Good Fortune
Legends say dwarven blood gave stronghearts their hardiness. Resistant to poison and wellsprings of endurance, these halflings easily hold their own.
Bane is the god of hatred, fear, and tyranny. His paladins are often remorseless commanders, leading armies dedicated to crushing the weak.
You have broken your sacred Oaths in pursuit of power and ambition. Only darkness remains to fuel you now.
Corellon Larethian, ever-changing creator of all elves, is both chaos and beauty personified. Their clerics are self-reliant and find a connection to their god by truly getting to know themselves.
Descended from the archdevil Mephistopheles, these tieflings are gifted with a particular affinity for arcane magic.
To be half-drow is to wrestle with a violent and complicated legacy. Cleverness and tenacity serve them well, for they are caught between two very different worlds.
Fela, A servant of Mielikki, Goddess of forests and patron of nature.
Being implanted with a mind flayer tadpole is a fate worse than death. Isn't it?
Bhaal is the god of murder. His paladins kill not only to please him, but as a sacred act that deepens Bhaal's influence on the world.
This sorcerer's powers come from ancient forces of chaos. They churn within - waiting to burst free at any time.
Laduguer is the patron of the duergar. His paladins are grim warriors who act as spearheads in the fight against the many dangerous forces of the Underdark.
Half-elves inherit blessings from both their parents, but at the price of never quite fitting in. Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere - yet struggle to stay for long.
With an ethereal countenance and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature and its power. Flourishing in light and darkness alike, an elf can be beautiful and terrifying in equal measure.
Lolth is the evil drow goddess of deceit, shadows, and spiders. While paladins of Lolth are rare, she sometimes bestows a gifted devotee with extra powers, drawing out an untapped potential.
Selne is the goddess of the moon, and her paladins are soldiers in the constant war against her dark sister Shar. They use her light to dispel darkness and relieve the pain of others.
One of the more common creatures to see in Faern, primarily defined as standing on two feet while being neither undead nor monstrous.
Shar is the goddess of darkness, loss, and secrets. Her paladins steal forbidden knowledge, poison the blessings of other gods, and murder those who serve Selne without a hint of remorse.

Shar is the goddess of darkness, secrets, and loss. Forever in conflict with her twin sister Selne, Shar's clerics poison the world with fear and suffering while stealing forbidden knowledge in her name.
Even smaller than their cousins and twice as reclusive, forest gnomes are a rare sight in Faern. They master magic and craftsmanship in their distant, idyllic groves.
Corellon Larethian, ever-changing creator of all elves. His paladins are protectors of all things beautiful and champions in the never-ending fight against the enemies of the elves.
Oghma is the Lord of Knowledge, overseeing inspiration and invention. His clerics spread truth, encourage innovation, and stamp out falsehoods wherever they go.

Kelemvor is the fair-minded judge of the dead, shepherding lost souls to the afterlife. His clerics perform burial rites and punish those who unnaturally extend their lifespans, such as liches and vampires.
Mountain dwarves thrive in rugged terrain, standing taller than their hill dwarf cousins. Their kingdoms are a bastion of strength in northern Faern.
This entity has been polymorphed into a delicious and presumably very perplexed cheese.
Garl Glittergold is the king of gnomish gods, a deity of humour, gem-cutting, protection, and trickery. His clerics are often artisans or storytellers, relaying his tenets to the younger generations.
Formally trained in a militia or army, soldiers know tactics and combat like the back of their hand.
Selne is the goddess of the moon, navigation, and lycanthropes. Her clerics honour Selne's empathy and mystique, but are fearsome when facing Selne's wicked sister, the goddess Shar.

The elves of the Underdark, drow have been fighting a massive civil war since the goddess Lolth severed herself from the elvish pantheon, a betrayal scarring every generation that followed. Drow city-states struggle with one another for dominance, but the true war is between the cultists who serve Lolth and those who resist the goddess' corruption.

Your skill in a particular craft has earned you membership in a mercantile guild, offering privileges and protection while engaging in your art. Discovering rare components for wondrous crafts will provide the perfect muse.
Neutral clerics uphold ideals of balance, fairness, and impartiality to further their faith. Helm, Kelemvor, Oghma, and Tempus are common gods they worship.
Evil paladins are merciless tyrants, willing to destroy whatever gets in their way. They swear Oaths to gods like Shar, Bhaal, Bane, and Myrkul.
Well-read and vigorous studies, sages always seek knowledge, often trading their own expertise for that of others.
Standing a head below most of Faern can be boon or bane, depending on whom one meets.
Monks use discipline and ritual to harness the energy inside their bodies, transforming it into explosive power. They excel at unarmed combat, for their defence is as strong as their spirit.
Named for their inclination to stealth, lightfoot halflings are nonetheless happy in the spotlight. They enjoy travel, and many have made names for themselves across Faern.
Myrkul is the god of death and decay. He has few clerics, but those who serve his faith inspire a fear of death in others, bringing doom wherever they tread.

Survivors of Lolth's treachery against Corellon Larethian, Seldarine drow live in a scattered collection of Underdark city-states, warring with each other as often as the Spider Queen's cult. Many of these drow travel to the surface in search of aid, seeking to reunite their shattered people at any cost.

The duergar - grey dwarves - were once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayer race, and adapted to freedom with a remarkably grim cruelty. Their stealth and viciousness makes them feared throughout the Underdark.
Rock gnomes are the most common to see on Faern's surface, named as such for their hardiness and affinity for metal.
As unparalleled scouts, rangers are in tune with the world around them, no matter how strange the terrain. They excel at hunting their favoured prey, tracking them without rest or relief.
Rock gnomes are the most common to see on Faern's surface, named as such for their hardiness and affinity for metal.
Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherit the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
Tieflings from Zariel's bloodline are empowered with martial strength, and can channel searing flame to punish their enemies.
Violence is both a means and an end. You follow a path of untrammelled fury, slick with blood, as you thrill in the chaos of battle, heedless of your own well-being.
With stealth, skill, and uncanny reflexes, rogues' versatility lets them get the upper hand in almost any situation.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The most common face to see in Faern, humans often face stiff competition from long-lived races, but hold their own with tenacity, creativity, and an endless capacity for growth.
Kelemvor is the judge of the dead. His paladins take on quests to destroy powerful undead, for their very existence subverts Kelemvor's will.
Legends say dwarven blood gave stronghearts their hardiness. Resistant to poison and wellsprings of endurance, these halflings easily hold their own.

Raised in one of Lolth's massive cults spread throughout the Underdark, these drow extol the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess, seeking to bring all other drow under her sway. Lolth marks her followers with vivid red eyes, in hope every race in Faern will learn to fear the very sight of them.
Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherit the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
Even smaller than their cousins and twice as reclusive, forest gnomes are a rare sight in Faern. They master magic and craftsmanship in their distant, idyllic groves.
Named for their inclination to stealth, lightfoot halflings are nonetheless happy in the spotlight. They enjoy travel, and many have made names for themselves across Faern.
Tyr is the god of justice, and his paladins are the sword that enforces this justice. They constantly hunt monsters and other wicked beings, for none may escape the Maimed God's sight.
A connoisseur of deals that are too good to be true. Prone to exaggeration, and more than happy to profit from it.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
A step further from the Feywild than their high elf parent, these half-elves still hold a magical spark. They mature faster than their brethren, but only live a few decades longer than humans.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells - by blood or curse - tieflings face constant suspicion in Faern. Their arcane abilities make them natural survivors, whether as heroes or villains.
Mystra is the goddess of all magic, guarding the Weave that allows mortal spellcasters to access its power. Her clerics preserve ancient lore and protect bastions of magic.
Eilistraee is a drow god of moonlight, song, swordwork and dance. Her paladins are tasked with coaxing other drow away from evil, and hunting the demonic agents of Lolth.
Durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faern.
Being raised in the Underdark casts a cruel shadow on one's view of the world, even up on the surface.

Bhaal is the notorious god of murder. He once spread his heritage and sadistic impulses through all of Faern, then resurrected himself in a horrific ritual. His clerics are assassins, deliberately killing to honour their god.
This sorcerer's veins carry draconic magic, the result of a powerful dragon ancestor.
Vlaakith is the dread lich queen of the githyanki. Anointed in a dark ritual, her paladins are chosen warriors who obey her every command.
Your patron is a mysterious entity whose nature is utterly foreign to the fabric of reality.
Hill dwarves are defined by their keen intuition and heightened senses. Their resilience has kept a massive kingdom in the south intact for centuries.
After surviving a childhood on the streets, you know how to make the most out of very little. Helping youth in need bolsters your spirit for the journey ahead.
Tyr is the god of law and justice, and encourages his clerics to uphold them no matter the sacrifices that must be made. He grants spells that enhance accuracy and martial prowess.

Moradin, the All-Father, is the god of the dwarf people, as well as the god of creation, smithing, stonework, and protection. His clerics guide the morals of dwarven communities and lead the charge against those who would assault them.
Committed to preserving life, you fight on the side of the light in the cosmic struggle against darkness.
To live is to perform, and entertainers know that best. Hard-earned skill with acrobatics and instruments is key when appealing to the masses.
Magic brews in a sorcerer's blood. By channelling natural talent into powerful spells, a sorcerer is born to arcane greatness.
A member of the chaotic evil fiends native to the Abyss.
You have made a pact with a fiend from the Lower Planes of existence, a being whose aims are evil, even if you strive against those aims.
Yondalla is the mother-goddess of the halflings. Following her example, her paladins devote their lives to protecting their communities.
A servant of the god of morning dawn, whose deific name is Lathander.
Eryn, A servant of Talos, God of Storms
You are pushed by greed and wanderlust, ever curious, seeking hoards and wonders unknown. Finding secret treasures opens the path to new discoveries.
Helm, the Vigilant One, is the god of those guard and defend others. His clerics serve as implacable sentries, often wearing heavy plate armour to emulate their deity.
Eilistraee is the goddess of good-aligned drow, beauty, song, and freedom. The Dark Maiden seeks to reconcile the ancient conflict between her people and those who live on Faern's surface.
Hill dwarves are defined by their keen intuition and heightened senses. Their resilience has kept a massive kingdom in the south intact for centuries.
Your previous oath was one of Vengeance.
A servant of the five-headed queen of dragons, Tiamat.
While not true dragons themselves, draconic lineage defines the dragonborn. They inherit powerful breath weapons from their ancestors and possess a preternatural toughness.
Venji, A servant of Mielikki, Goddess of forests and patron of nature.
Kulishov, A servant of Tymora, Goddess of Good Fortune

Although they descend from cultures of strength and martial prowess, most half-orcs are born in times of peace. Whenever orcish wars end, alliances and marriages lead to a new generation of shared blood.
While not true dragons themselves, draconic lineage defines the dragonborn. They inherit powerful breath weapons from their ancestors and possess a preternatural toughness.
Casting aside even your own purity, you deliver justice to those who have committed the most grievous sins.

When a feckless amateur spellcaster attempts to create life, and bungles it, the result is a Gremishka. Spiteful, malformed, and hideously feline, Gremishka's hold a particular loathing for practitioners of the arcane arts, a dark reflection of typical parental love.
A servant of Bahamut, God of metallic dragons.
A servant of the five-headed queen of dragons, Tiamat.
Enro, A servant of Lathander, God of the dawn.
Kosen, A servant of Talos, God of Storms
Deva, an Angel in Service to a God
A servant of Bahamut, god of metallic dragons.
Olov, Cleric of Gruumsh, God of Conquest
Sim, A servant of Gruumsh One-Eye, God of Conquest and patron of orcs.

Although they descend from cultures of strength and martial prowess, most half-orcs are born in times of peace. Whenever orcish wars end, alliances and marriages lead to a new generation of shared blood.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
A charmer and a rake with the most dangerous smile in Baldur's Gate.
For exposing Kagha's corruption, you have been honoured by the druids as a defender of nature and balance.
Shar's loyal pupil, desperate to fulfil her holy mission.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Character who scrying eye has no interest in
A brand of the Absolute marks this person's arm, displaying loyalty to the rest of the cult.
Those raised in Baldur's Gate know the city well, for better or worse.
Shar's loyal pupil, desperate to fulfil her holy mission.
Dealing with hags always comes with a cost. In this case, an eye.
No warrior is more ferocious, no githyanki more loyal to Vlaakith.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
A high-ranked servant of the Absolute, empowered by the god's will.
No warrior is more ferocious, no githyanki more loyal to Vlaakith.
A charmer and a rake with the most dangerous smile in Baldur's Gate.
Creature has assumed the shape of a beast.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The enigmatic wizard of Waterdeep and devotee of Mystra.
The enigmatic wizard of Waterdeep and devotee of Mystra.
Tag to define things in the Ghost Dog's mausoleum that they will protect
Tag is given on Ravengard if Mizora's summons are attacking him in the Iron Throne
Target for Mizora's spiders if they can't reach Ravengard because he climbed the ladder
Targets that should be ignored by the Kuo-Toa net
You are a Dark Justiciar of Shar
%%% Viconia: Target's Fear = Turning into a Mindflayer
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Companion has some tadpoles slotted in.
Set on players who are considered dead at the end of the Iron Throne
Jaheira's storied history of adventure would simply take too long to relate. Let this suffice: she takes no nonsense, but she does take heads.
Prevents the same AD from being selected in two VBs.
Lae'zel is on the Orpheus path.
Jaheira's storied history of adventure would simply take too long to relate. Let this suffice: she takes no nonsense, but she does take heads.
Companion Does not want to use Tadpole Powers
Not a crumb of tobacco in this pipe.
Use to fill a smoking pipe with aromatic tobacco.
A smoking pipe without any frills.
To fill the pipe you need a tobacco pouch.
The simplest mixture of herbs, used for smoking throughout the Forgotten Realms.
The pungent aroma of garlic and spices is permanently ground into this stone bowl.
Though the mortar and pestle both look clean, the old wood is infused with an acrid smell.

Gilded tools are no luxury for any serious alchemist. While wood is hard to clean, metal often binds to its contents, sometimes with disastrous consequences. A thin layer of gold solves both these problems.
The pipe is filled with regular tobacco, which gives the smoker a short-term concentration.

Affected entity's ability to maintain its spells has increased.

It has Advantage to Saving Throws against being Charmed and for maintaining Concentration.
This mix of mugwort and mergrass gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_MERGRASS_STATUS">a little insight</LSTag>.
The simplest mixture of herbs, used for smoking throughout the Forgotten Realms.
The pipe is filled with Swamp Tobacco, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_MERGRASS_STATUS">a little insight</LSTag>.
The pipe is filled with Underdark Tobacco, which improves smokers' <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_MUGWORT_UNDERDARKMUSHROOMS_STATUS">vision in the dark</LSTag>.
The pipe is filled with Cursed Tobacco, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_SHADOWROOTSAC_STATUS">malice and temporary protection</LSTag> from the Shadow Curse.
The pipe is filled with Noble Tobacco, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_PALEMINT_STATUS">an aura of nobility</LSTag>.
Tobacco mix of mugwort and underdark mushrooms improves smokers' <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_MUGWORT_UNDERDARKMUSHROOMS_STATUS">vision in the dark</LSTag>.
A rather rare tobacco blend, which is indulged mainly by the inhabitants of the Underdark.

Smelly mix of mugwort and powder from a shadowroot sac gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_SHADOWROOTSAC_STATUS">temporary protection</LSTag> from the Shadow Curse and malice.
A very rare and terribly smelly blend that you won't find anywhere except in the Shadow-cursed lands.
A most aromatic blend of mugwort and pale mint, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_BELLADONNA_PALEMINT_STATUS">an aura of nobility</LSTag>.
Noble tobacco, not everyone even in Baldur's Gate can afford it.
Used for mixing various herbs, including tobacco blends.
Even the smell of tobacco makes you <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KAP_TOBACCO_OVERDOSE_5">Sick</LSTag>... It's better to take a break from smoking.

Frequent smoking causes the character to feel unwell. He has difficulty concentrating on spells and has Disadvantage on Dexterity Checks.
If you continue to smoke without a long rest, you may experience Headaches.

Frequent smoking caused headaches. In addition to the problems caused by Malaise, oncentrating on spells is even more difficult and there was also an Disadvantage on Charisma Checks and Attack Rolls.
If you continue to smoke without a long rest, you may experience Nicotine Toxicity.

The character is poisoned by nicotine. He take an additional [1], cannot cast, it's <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_OVERDOSE_4_REMOVE_STATUSES">almost impossible</LSTag> to concentrate on spells anymore and has <LSTag Tooltip="Disadvantage">Disadvantage</LSTag> on all Abilities <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Checks</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.

A Malaise requires a <LSTag Tooltip="DifficultyClass">DC</LSTag> [1] Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throw</LSTag> or the effects of smoking will be removed and concentration spells will cease to work.

A Headaches requires a <LSTag Tooltip="DifficultyClass"> DC</LSTag> [1] Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throw</LSTag> or the effects of smoking will be removed and concentration spells will cease to work.

A Nicotine Toxicity requires a <LSTag Tooltip="DifficultyClass"> DC</LSTag> [1] Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throw</LSTag> or the effects of smoking will be removed and concentration spells will cease to work.

Belladonna leaves in regular blend gives the smoker <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> to <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> for maintaining <LSTag Tooltip="Concentration">Concentration</LSTag> and immunity to magical sleep spells.
Crushed mergrass in a swamp tobacco blend gives the smoker <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> in Deception and Persuasion.

Underdark mushrooms mixed into tobacco gives the ability to see in the dark out to a range of [1] and gained a +1 bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> against targets standing in darkness or dim light.

A foul-smelling blend with powder from a shadowroot sac provides temporary resistance to the Shadow Curse and number you need to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">roll</LSTag> a <LSTag Tooltip="CriticalHit">Critical Hit</LSTag> while attacking is reduced by 1, but you are <LSTag Tooltip="Vulnerable">Vulnerable</LSTag> to Necrotic damage and your vitality reduces by [1].

The exquisite aroma of this tobacco gives self-confidence and opens many doors.
The smoker gets Proficiency in Deception, Intimidation, Performance, and Persuasion, an extra bonus action and can't be Charmed.
The pipe is filled with Underdark Tobacco, which gives the smoker <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KAP_TOBACCO_UNDERDARK_STATUS">ability to see in the dark</LSTag>.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> against Lightly or Heavily Obscured targets when using this blade.
* smoking slightly reduces initiative and physical abilities.
* smoking slightly reduces initiative and physical abilities.

Smoking slightly reduces initiative and physical abilities (-[1]) and can lead to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_OVERDOSE_3">Malaise</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_OVERDOSE_4">Headaches</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="KTP_OVERDOSE_5">Nicotine Toxicity</LSTag>.

Regular Blend - gives the smoker Advantage to Saving Throws for maintaining Concentration and immunity to magical sleep spells.
Ingredients: Mugwort + Belladonna.

Swamp Blend - gives the smoker Proficiency in Deception and Persuasion.
Ingredients: Mugwort + Mergrass.

Underdark Blend - gives the ability to see in the dark out to a range of 18 and gained a +1 bonus to Attack Rolls against targets standing in darkness or dim light.
Ingredients: Mugwort + Underdark mushroom.

Cursed Blend - provides temporary resistance to the Shadow Curse and number you need to roll a Critical Hit while attacking is reduced by 1, but you are Vulnerable to Necrotic damage and your vitality reduces by 3.
Ingredients: Mugwort + Shadowroot Sac.

Noble Blend - gives self-confidence and opens many doors. The smoker gets Proficiency in Deception, Intimidation, Performance, and Persuasion, an extra bonus action and can't be Charmed.
Ingredients: Mugwort + Pale Mint.

SMOKER'S NOTES
* for storing notes on smoking.
A clean scroll, useful for writing
A pouch of tobacco, but what kind of blend is unclear... Is it worth trying to smoke it?
A small leather pouch with a drawstring, usually used for storing tobacco.
The pipe is filled with an unknown blend... Is it worth trying to smoke it or is it not worth experimenting?
